awd_titl_txt: Data Path: Creating a New STEM Pathway for Undergraduates from Statistics Into Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by increasing the number and diversity of STEM students.  To do so, it will establish a new path into STEM majors and careers through statistics and data science for students at a Hispanic-serving two-year college. This new path is expected to improve STEM learning and teaching and increase the diversity of students pursuing STEM. The first step in the pathway will be a redesigned Introduction to Statistics course that incorporates project-based learning.  This change is expected to engage more students and spark their interest in pursuing a STEM pathway.   The next step in the pathway will be a new introduction to Data Science course, which will meet a transfer math requirement  The Data Science course is expected to serve as an onramp into STEM for students who do not necessarily see themselves in a STEM career.  The project will actively recruit students from the new statistics course into the new Data Science course, thus transforming the statistics course into a STEM talent pipeline instead of a terminal math course.  Additional students will be recruited into the Data Science course via a new Data Scholars Program, which will provide a supportive STEM community for students who may not be initially interested in STEM majors.  Finally, the project will provide professional development to mathematics faculty on implementing project-based curriculum pedagogy. 

A quasi-experimental design will be used to measure the overall effectiveness of project-based learning in the introductory statistics course. Students in the new project-based learning statistics course will be compared with students in statistics courses using traditional pedagogy. Analysis of variance will be used to examine differences between the two types of courses on measures of student experience, student attendance, course success, degree completion, and transfer rate to four-year universities. Furthermore, qualitative methods, such as focus groups and open-ended survey questions, will be used to evaluate the fidelity of implementing the project-based learning model. This project project may serve as a model for other community colleges looking to build a data science program and a new pathway into STEM. Lessons learned and insights gained into how changing pedagogy impacts student interest and success in STEM will be shared through conference presentations and publications. Anticipated outcomes during the project period include increased student success rates in the project-based statistics course, increased enrollment in the data science course, and increased participation in the Data Scholars program.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The DataPath project aimed to create an alternate pathway into STEM through statistics and data science by engaging non-STEM majors in project-based learning in an Introductory Statistics course. This was accomplished by adopting the Passion Driven Statistics curriculum, offering ongoing faculty professional development, and establishing a Data Scholars community to support students. The Intro Stats curriculum was redesigned, giving students the opportunity to work with real data and learning statistics in the context of answering the research questions they developed.  The hands-on experience of coding and working on real-world projects allowed students to engage more deeply with the material, building practical skills beyond theoretical knowledge. Instructors appreciated the collaborative nature of the approach, professional development through the Statistics Community of Practice, and many enjoyed working in a less traditional classroom environment.

While the project resulted in few students switching to data science majors, it broadened access to STEM and promoted interdisciplinary engagement. The redesigned Intro Stats course, which emphasized using real-world data and project-based learning, sparked strong interest in coding and statistics from non-STEM majors, with surveys showing that about two-thirds of students wanted to learn more by the end of the course. Despite this interest, motivating students to switch to data science majors was challenging, especially for those in fields like psychology or sociology, where there is little overlap between required courses those majors and data science. While some students expressed interest in double majoring or minoring in data science, the structure at community colleges made such transitions difficult, with students overwhelmed by additional course requirements. However, the upcoming Data Science Certificate of Achievement, pending approval by the state chancellor's office, will formally recognize students' data science coursework, offering a more structured pathway for those interested in further study.

A key strategy for broadening access to STEM was the project's emphasis on advertising and recruitment through collaborations with established campus programs like the STEM Center, Math Engineering Science Achievement (MESA), and the Promise Scholars Program, the latter two groups which primarily serve underrepresented students. The project team organized a range of events from low-stakes, short-term activities such as weekly beginner Python for Data Science workshops, the Women in Data Science Conference field trip, and meeting data scientists through the long-standing Science in Action speaker series to longer term activities like DataJam to give students different opportunities to engage with data science.  By leveraging these established programs, the project team streamlined event planning and recruitment efforts, effectively reaching a wider audience. Many Intro Stats students participated in these events, especially the shorter-term workshops and field trips.

The creation of the Data Scholars community played a critical role in transforming the campus culture surrounding STEM. Previously, students in STEM majors often worked in silos, but the community encouraged interdisciplinary collaboration, with students from different fields working together in activities like Python workshops and DataJam. This collaborative environment helped students build technical skills, expand their peer networks, and gain exposure to a variety of STEM career paths. The DataPath project resulted in engaged students and faculty, and a growing and thriving Data Scholars community.
